instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7090: What is U7090? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V42_G3H.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.D7012: What is D7012? Diode between ground and gate of Q7010 on 2013-2015 year model macbook airs, necessary for Q7010 to allow PPDCIN_G3H to flow through to PP3V42_G3H power supply input. When this diode dies or corrodes, PP3V42_G3H input will not have any voltage, and chargers will not turn on. This can often be the problem if a system only works with a knockoff charger/bench power supply. .
definitions.Q7010: What is Q7010? Q7010 controls whether or not PPDCIN_G3H will be let through to the PP3V42_G3H power supply, often this circuit area is not working because D7010 has died or corroded. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
No green light, no fan spin.
New flex cable tried and no go.
<CHIP>U7090</CHIP> looks terrible. See image below.
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is 0V needless to say

0V at L7095

Tons of corrosion at <CHIP>U7090</CHIP>.
I don't like to just throw a board into a US cleaner but I am considering doing so on this one.
I can't even measure voltages at <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> as pins 5-8 look like crap.
<RESISTOR>R7012</RESISTOR> has 14.95-15.02 V


[ATTACH type="full" alt="<SIGNAL>IMG_0015</SIGNAL>.jpg"]59906[/ATTACH]


I have been away from repair from 3 months so I am a bit rusty.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Remove <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> and resolder its pads, as on the board too; may need new chip.
Replace corroded components and rebuild traces, if necessary.
I don't recommend UC, if no other areas affected; scrub locally with alcohol and toothbrush.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
OK, replaced <CHIP>U7090</CHIP>
Rebuilt traces

Now I shifted focus to <TRANSISTOR>Q7010</TRANSISTOR>
PIN 5: 15.10
PIN 4: 14.9

The gate is way too high.
<RESISTOR>R7010</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7011</RESISTOR> are correct ohms
<RESISTOR>R7012</RESISTOR> is correct

Could this be <DIODE>D7012</DIODE>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
replaced <DIODE>D7012</DIODE>.
Now have green light.
No fan spin

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> now at 8.60V

USB PORT is working.

<CHIP>U7400</CHIP> PIN 12: <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>: 1.22V
DIODE MODE, pin 12 here is 0.447V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
"USB PORT is working"
I doubt, if you don't get RAM voltage.
Read "HOW TO collection" thread about how to confirm USB activity.

"<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>: 1.22V"
You shouldn't have <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> in this case.
Post basic <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> voltages; pins 23, 12, 13, 22, 29, 21.
Also check diode mode to ground at pins 22, 29 and L7520/60.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7560</CHIP>

6,7,8: 0 V
1: 8.60V



<CHIP>U7501</CHIP>
4: 0 V
12: 3.40
13: 0
21: 3.39
22: 0
23: 1.07
25: 0.62 V
26: 1.06
29: 1.23

DIODE
22: .55V
29: 0.45V

L7520: .426V
L7560: 0.36V

NOTICED
<CAPACITOR>C7581</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7583</CAPACITOR> missing endcaps
replaced them
FAN SPIN!!
